title: Introduction
text:
What is Causal Inference
Imagine you want to know whether a teaching method you‚Äôve learned about in GS750 really helps students in your class. You notice that students who took the class with these new implementations seem to get higher scores. But wait ‚Äî maybe those students were already more motivated, or had more free time. How can you tell if it was really the teaching method that caused the improvement?
Causal inference is all about answering that kind of question: What actually causes what? It‚Äôs the science of figuring out the effect of one thing on another.
To do this, researchers try to compare groups that are as similar as possible ‚Äî except for the thing they‚Äôre testing (like the new teaching method). One simple way to do that is a randomized experiment, where some students are randomly chosen to get the new method (the ‚Äútreatment‚Äù) and others are not (the ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù). Because the assignment is random, the groups are fair, and any difference in outcomes can be attributed to the treatment itself.
So, causal inference is like being a detective for cause-and-effect: you look carefully at the data, make sure groups are comparable, and try to figure out whether a change in one thing really leads to a change in another.

title: Welcome
text: Welcome to the casual introduction to Causal Inference!
